content: XXXhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7930837.stmXXX Two shot dead at Antrim army base It is believed that there were two long busts of gunfire during the incident Two military personnel have been shot dead during a gun attack at an Army base in County Antrim, police said. No-one has so far claimed responsibility. The attack comes shortly after Sir Hugh Orde, the chief constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland, requested the Special Reconnaissance Regiment's help to gather intelligence on dissident republicans. In 2008, dissident republicans attempted to kill PSNI officers during separate incidents in Derry City and Dungannon, Co Tyrone. Security forces defused a 300lb (136kg) bomb in Castlewellan, Co Down, close to a barracks in February 2009. Sounds like the return of PIRA scum. RIP to the Soldiers Lost

title: Terrorrist Attack in Northern Ireland

content: Ireland does tend to be cyclical - as soon as one bunch of terrs has apparently given up or made peace there's a brief hiatus and another mob turns up. Often containing some familiar faces and using familiar weapons (I was once told that ballistics reckoned that one particular weapon had been used in crimes claimed by three supposedly different organisations.) Of course if this is a genuinely "off the book" atrocity then the perpetrators can expect to have ticked off the Provisionals - who would rather their lucrative crime empire wasn't too closely observed - and be met with the full force of injustice. If a couple of lads turn up dead in a ditch over the next few weeks we'll know.

content: According to the BBC it's been announced that the "Real" IRA has claimed responsibility with a credible password Ruanne, so I think we can be fairly sure it's Players of some form. By the way it is vanishingly rare for criminals of any variety bar terrorists to take any sort of action against soldiers on camp and the sort of incident reported almost never happens in Britain or Ireland outside of inter-gang crime in the major cities.

content: Didnt some stupid politician get the noble peace price for striking a so called peace agreement with the IRA? When will they learn!
reply: Didnt some stupid politician get the noble peace price for striking a so called peace agreement with the IRA? When will they learn!
title: Terrorrist Attack in Northern Ireland

content: quote: Originally posted by TheGoodOne: Didnt some stupid politician get the noble peace price for striking a so called peace agreement with the IRA? When will they learn! David Trimble, then leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP - he's a Conservative peer now) and John Hume, leader of the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP, an Irish Nationalist Party) shared the 1998 Peace Prize. Neither is particularly stupid, not least because they managed to persuade Sinn Fein/IRA to negotiate rather than flog the increasingly sick horse that was their terror campaign. The R(eal)IRA is still very small beer compared with the Provisionals. The important thing to remember is that Hume and Trimble gave the IRA a way out when their campaign stalled without which things might have got very much nastier (the analogy of the cornered rat is apposite here).
quote: Originally posted by TheGoodOne: Didnt some stupid politician get the noble peace price for striking a so called peace agreement with the IRA? When will they learn!
reply: David Trimble, then leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP - he's a Conservative peer now) and John Hume, leader of the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP, an Irish Nationalist Party) shared the 1998 Peace Prize. Neither is particularly stupid, not least because they managed to persuade Sinn Fein/IRA to negotiate rather than flog the increasingly sick horse that was their terror campaign. The R(eal)IRA is still very small beer compared with the Provisionals. The important thing to remember is that Hume and Trimble gave the IRA a way out when their campaign stalled without which things might have got very much nastier (the analogy of the cornered rat is apposite here).

content: quote: Originally posted by Ruanne: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: XXXhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7930837.stmXXX Two shot dead at Antrim army base It is believed that there were two long busts of gunfire during the incident Two military personnel have been shot dead during a gun attack at an Army base in County Antrim, police said. No-one has so far claimed responsibility. The attack comes shortly after Sir Hugh Orde, the chief constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland, requested the Special Reconnaissance Regiment's help to gather intelligence on dissident republicans. In 2008, dissident republicans attempted to kill PSNI officers during separate incidents in Derry City and Dungannon, Co Tyrone. Security forces defused a 300lb (136kg) bomb in Castlewellan, Co Down, close to a barracks in February 2009. Sounds like the return of PIRA scum. RIP to the Soldiers Lost Which, in turn, explains the return of British military intelligence and surveillance units to NI. Or vice versa. LOL about the vice versa. Don't know if this was terrorism or just some criminals targeting military guys to start up trouble. Maybe one of the soldiers had even made some enemies, and everyone else was just a bystander. I'm not jumping to any conclusions, but then I know nothing outside of this AP/Reuters version of the story. The purported 'criminality' is part of the civilised gloss laid over what, from the look of it, continues to resemble what it was all along - two armed camps - or, at least,now one armed camp - divided on virtually every issue that appears in the news. Meanwhile the police service continues to 'police' as effectively as it is allowed. Which might engender a desire to get rid of those vestiges of 'criminal' resistance. In this case using a 'proven' method - military intelligence. There's still a strong sensation of 'sell-out', on both sides, now that the US mediator has moved on. Armed protestant paramilitaries still remain a tool, and a threat ... no decommissioning weapons for those lads. Those recent 'reconciliation payments' were a farce - and an insult to many. Not a good idea. Ulster is a brilliant example that money doesn't solve problems and creates more of its own. more bad news: >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7934426.stm This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Tue 10 March 2009 06:08 AM

content: quote: Originally posted by Bladensburg: According to the BBC it's been announced that the "Real" IRA has claimed responsibility with a credible password Ruanne, so I think we can be fairly sure it's Players of some form. By the way it is vanishingly rare for criminals of any variety bar terrorists to take any sort of action against soldiers on camp and the sort of incident reported almost never happens in Britain or Ireland outside of inter-gang crime in the major cities. Wasn't the 'Real' IRA responsible for the bombing shortly after the Good Friday Peace Accord? Nasty bit of business, one of the highest mortalities with that bombing done in a shopping center. Not the usual area where there might be a police station or an area where soldiers could be found.

content: quote: Originally posted by 67NOV: quote: Originally posted by Bladensburg: According to the BBC it's been announced that the "Real" IRA has claimed responsibility with a credible password Ruanne, so I think we can be fairly sure it's Players of some form. content: quote: Originally posted by Bladensburg: quote: Originally posted by 67NOV: quote: Originally posted by Bladensburg: According to the BBC it's been announced that the "Real" IRA has claimed responsibility with a credible password Ruanne, so I think we can be fairly sure it's Players of some form. Twenty-nine dead thanks to an apparently deliberately unclear warning. That 'unclear' warning is, I've read, the reason for later charges of police negligence and incompetence. The 'deliberate' part is debatable because the effect of police action, based on that warning isn't. A lot of people were shepherded into the blast zone.

content: In a tremendous outpouring of grief and solidarity against violence, the people of Ulster took to the streets to voice their position. The police announced the arrests of two men in connection with the killing of a police officer. >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7935734.stm

content: NIPS announced to-day the arrest of 3 man in connection with the attack on the Army Barracks. One of those arrested was identified as an 'IRA leader' at the time of the ceasefire agreement. >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7944352.stm At the same time the head of the NIPS claims that only a 'handful' of Ulstermen are inclined to terror. However, they present a 'dire threat' and require the intervention of military force? >http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7944544.stm There were no terrorists when police bungled the protests of 1967. By the way it is vanishingly rare for criminals of any variety bar terrorists to take any sort of action against soldiers on camp and the sort of incident reported almost never happens in Britain or Ireland outside of inter-gang crime in the major cities. Wasn't the 'Real' IRA responsible for the bombing shortly after the Good Friday Peace Accord? Nasty bit of business, one of the highest mortalities with that bombing done in a shopping center. Not the usual area where there might be a police station or an area where soldiers could be found. It was Market Street, Omagh, Co. Tyrone, 15th Aug 1998. Twenty-nine dead thanks to an apparently deliberately unclear warning. That 'unclear' warning is, I've read, the reason for later charges of police negligence and incompetence. The 'deliberate' part is debatable because the effect of police action, based on that warning isn't. A lot of people were shepherded into the blast zone.
reply: Bollocks, anybody familiar with Omagh would have known for a start that the street in question was Market Street, not High Street or Main Street or anything else. The warning was intended to confuse and slow down the response while providing a fig leaf of "...we tried to warn you.." to murderous scum.
title: Terrorrist Attack in Northern Ireland

content: Couldnt agree more Bladsey, one of the arrested men is Colin Duffy who lives on the Kilwilkie estate in Lurgan. Whilst serving at Drumadd Bks with the Armagh EOD team, it was pretty quiet, until that is Mr. Duffy was released. Activity shot up markedly and can only be attributed to the locals being **** scared of him! We carried out three planned ops on that bloody main line whilst that murderous ******* just leared at us. (A good combat indicator nothing was going to happen though!) Low level violence and imtimidation continues in Province, it just isnt reported widely outside NI. Duffy was already convicted of the murder of two RUC officers, but released early under the terms of the GFA. IF, if he is found guilty they should throw away the key.
